I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During  the  Country  Consultation  Mission  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  in 
September  2001,  the  Government  of  the  Fiji  Islands  requested  ADB  to  provide  technical 
assistance (TA) to prepare a proposal for a rural electrification project. The TA is included in the 
2002 country strategy and program. The Fact-Finding Mission visited the Fiji Islands in March 
2002  and  reached  an  understanding  on  the  TA’s  rationale,  purpose  and  output,  terms  of 
reference, cost estimates, and implementation arrangements with the Government and the 
concerned agencies. The logical framework is attached as Appendix 1.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The  long-term  objective  of  the  country’s  rural  electrification  policy  is  to  provide 
continuous electricity to all potential electricity consumers in the Fiji Islands. Prior to 1993, the 
rural electrification program was implemented by the Public Works Department (PWD) based on 
a cost-sharing arrangement (consumers cater for 1/3 of the cost, the Government pays the 
2/3rds); and by other Government agencies on full-cost subsidy arrangement (i.e., consumers 
pay no part of the cost) with funds obtained on an ad hoc basis, through aid agencies. During 
1975 to 1992, 203 electrification schemes were installed. The Government owned the schemes 
and had the obligation to maintain and eventually replace them. However, the connection policy 
was uncoordinated and unplanned and, with restricted budgetary allocations, the Government 
was not able to maintain these services.2 
 
3.  In  order  to  achieve  consistency  in  the  connection  policy  and  sustainability  in  the 
operation and maintenance (O&M) of the rural electrification supply, the Government approved 
a new rural electrification policy in 1993. The Rural Electrification Unit was created within the 
Department  of  Energy  (DOE)3  with  responsibility  to  administer  and  control  the  rural 
electrification  program.  With  the  new  system,  each  village  or  settlement  requiring  rural 
electrification assistance contributes 10% and the Government subsidizes 90% of the total 
capital cost. The village/settlement owns the electrification scheme and, after a grace period of 
three  years,4  it  becomes  responsible  for  its  maintenance.  The  rural  electrification  policy 
contemplates  different  options  for  electrification,  including  (i)  Fiji  Electricity  Authority  (FEA) 
connection to the grid; (ii) Government station connection; (iii) stand-alone diesel; and (iv) 
renewable energy based schemes such as hydro, solar, and biomass. Since the adoption of the 
1993 rural electrification policy, 454 rural communities throughout the Fiji Islands were provided 
with  electricity  services,  mostly  stand-alone  diesel  (48.2%)  and  FEA  connection  (46.9%) 
schemes.5 
 
4.  There is a growing demand for 24 hour electricity and backup facilities to guide the 
schemes  toward  sustainable  operations.  However,  the  Rural  Electrification  Unit  remains 
understaffed6  and  underfinanced.  This  reduces  dramatically  the  effectiveness  of  the  rural

electrification program and constrains the Government’s effort to increase basic services and 
reduce the extent of poverty in the rural areas of the Fiji Islands. 
 
5.  There  is  a  strong  preference  among  the  external  funding  community  to  promote 
renewable energy sources in the Fiji Islands. ADB is not the only assistance agency assisting 
the  Fiji  Islands  in  developing  renewable  energy  supply.  Coordination  among  funders  is 
important  to  complement  and  build  synergies  and  avoid  duplication.  DOE  is  currently 
implementing  a  project  funded  by  Global  Environment  Facility  (GEF)  and  United  Nations 
Development  Programme  (UNDP).  The  project  aims  to  improve  the  current  institutional 
structure and allow the involvement/establishment of renewable energy service companies in 
rural areas. The project will be completed in August 2003. Furthermore, the Economic and 
Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (ESCAP) is considering assisting the Government in 
reviewing the 1993 Rural Electrification policy. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
6.  The TA will establish a development strategy and investment plan for rural electrification 
with special emphasis on optimizing extension of the FEA electrical grid, building new diesel-
power  capacity,  and  providing  renewable  energy  supply  (e.g.,  micro-hydro,  biomass,  solar 
photovoltaic,  and  hybrid  systems).  The  TA  will  assess  the  social,  institutional,  and 
environmental  aspects  of  rural  electrification,  and  recommend  appropriate  development 
strategies. It will also identify and carry out a feasibility study and develop a rural electrification 
project suitable for financing by ADB and other external funding agencies, and assess its long-
term sustainability. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
7.  The TA will consist of (i) a full review of the rural electrification supply in the Fiji Islands, 
(ii) prioritization of rural energy development strategy and investment plans to reduce poverty, 
and (iii) preparation of a project suitable for financing by ADB and/or other agencies. The TA will 
be implemented in two phases. 
 
8.  Phase I will (i) review the relevant studies of rural electrification in the Fiji Islands; (ii) 
assess the strengths and weaknesses of the present arrangement and suggest improvements; 
(iii) propose institutional improvement suitable to ensure efficient implementation of the rural 
electrification sector; (iv) forecast rural electrification demand; (v) formulate a long-term least-
cost investment program that will meet the assessed demand and will maximize economic, 
social, and poverty impact; and (vi) in close consultation with stakeholders, formulate a realistic 
five-year investment plan for extension of electricity supply through expansion of the grid system 
and construction of new generation systems, including diesel and renewable energy supply. 
 
9.  Based on the results of phase I, phase II will develop a rural electrification project 
suitable for external financing. Phase II will (i) identify the highest priority components of the 
project for ADB financing in terms of poverty impact; (ii) prepare a feasibility level design for the 
project, include scope, components, cost estimates, implementation arrangements, and O&M 
procedures; (iii) undertake a detailed socioeconomic survey, initial environmental examination, 
resettlement plan (if needed), and financial and economic evaluation of the project; (iv) assess 
the implementation capacity and future O&M capacity, and willingness/ability to pay for the 
service;  and  (v)  propose  institutional  improvement  (including  private  sector  participation)

3 
suitable to ensure efficient implementation of the project; (vi) provide inputs for developing 
regulatory frameworks; and (vii) recommend sustainable measures to be adopted to ensure that 
the poor can avail of electricity services. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
10.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $573,000 equivalent, consisting of $350,000 in 
foreign exchange costs and $223,000 equivalent in local currency cost. The Government has 
requested ADB to finance $400,000 equivalent, covering the entire foreign exchange cost and 
$50,000 equivalent of the local cost. The financing will be provided on a grant basis from the 
Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The Government will finance the 
remaining local currency cost of $173,000 equivalent. The detailed cost estimates and financing 
plan are shown in Appendix 2. The Government has been advised that ADB’s approval of the 
TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing program or project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
11.  DOE  of  the  Ministry  for  Works,  Telecommunications,  Energy,  Road  Transport,  and 
Shipping, will be the Executing Agency for the TA. DOE will establish a project unit with a full-
time project manager with qualifications acceptable to ADB. The Government will provide all 
available  relevant  information  and  facilitate  the  collection  of  socioeconomic  data.  The 
Government will also help ensure adequate cooperation from FEA, local government bodies, 
and nongovernment organizations active in the project area. The director for energy will be 
responsible for overall coordination among DOE, the consultants, ADB, the Government, and 
nongovernment organizations. 
 
12.  The TA will be carried out by an international consulting engineering firm, supported by 
associated domestic consultants, with relevant experience in all aspects of the specified scope 
of work. The consultant will be selected through the quality and cost-based selection method 
and  the  simplified  technical  proposal  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants, or by other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of domestic 
consultants. Approximately 12 person-months for services of international consultants and 8 of 
domestic consultants will be required. The equipment will be procured by the consultants in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  procurement  guidelines.  The  international  consultants  will  have 
expertise in (i) rural electrification system planning, design, construction, and operation (team 
leader7);  (ii)  renewable  energy  sources  development;  (iii)  rural  electrification  financial  and 
economic analysis; (iv) poverty impact assessment; and (v) environmental, regulatory, and 
social  analysis.  The  domestic  consultants  will  have  expertise  in  (i)  rural  electrification 
economics, (ii) renewable energy, (iii) socioeconomic analysis, and (iv) community development 
and participation. 
 
13.  The TA is expected to commence in March 2003 and be completed by March 2004. 
Within 4 weeks after commencement, the consultants will submit an inception report detailing 
initial findings and a refined action plan for conducting the study. A phase I report will be 
submitted within 4 months from commencement of the TA, will set forth the findings of phase I 
and will recommend the direction of work for phase II. Within 4 weeks of receipt of the phase I 
report, the Government and ADB will convene the first tripartite meeting in Suva to review the 
report.  Within  6  months  of  this  first  tripartite  meeting  (or  about  9  months  from  the 
commencement of the TA), the consultants will submit a draft final report covering phases I and

draft final report within 4 weeks of its submission. Based on these discussions, the consultants 
will finalize and submit the final report within 2 months. Based on this schedule, the TA will be

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
14.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
 
the Government of the Fiji Islands for Preparing the Rural Electrification Project, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Phase I (approximately 3 person-months international, 2 person-months domestic) 
1.  The energy/power specialist consultants will perform tasks in the general review of the 
sector, development of a program for the rural electrification, and formulation of an investment 
plan for the electrification. 
2.  For the general review of the sector, the consultants will 
(i)  gather  and  review  all  relevant  statistics,  including  population,  demographics, 
income,  poverty,  and  other  information  about  the  characteristics  of  the  rural 
areas in the Fiji Islands; 
(ii)  review all currently available and ongoing studies related to rural electrification, 
including studies on electrification with connection to the national grid network, 
stand-alone diesel, and renewable energy as appropriate for application in the 
rural areas; and 
(iii)  review the Government’s development policies and investment plans prepared 
and/or implemented for rural electrification and renewable energy. 
 
3.  To develop a program for rural electrification, the consultants will 
(i)  present a concise and clear picture of rural electrification in the Fiji Islands, with 
particular  attention  to  the  electrification  ratio  and  use  of  fuels,  regulatory 
framework, institutional arrangements, impact on consumers, and whether the 
main rural electrification objectives are achieved; 
(ii)  review  recent  experiences  and  lessons  learned  on  renewable  energy 
development  in  rural  areas  and  propose  ways  to  increase  their  viability/ 
sustainability; 
(iii)  conduct  socioeconomic  surveys  to  collect  and  compile  data  required  for 
developing  rural  electrification  strategy,  and  identify  major  policy  issues  and 
constraints impeding the development and efficient operation of power supply in 
the rural areas; 
(iv)  assess  the  custom  land  ownership  in  the  area,  examine  the  need  for  land 
acquisition, and prepare the Resettlement Framework in accordance with the 
Guidelines for Resettlement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB); 
(v)  value the full operation and maintenance costs of the rural electrification system 
and assess whether the present arrangement is consistent with the subsidy 
policy of ADB; 
(vi)  develop  electricity  demand  forecasts  for  the  different  consumer  groups  and 
prepare  a  15  year  perspective  plan  for  rural  electrification;  and  assess 
quantitatively and qualitatively the impact of providing electricity to the rural areas 
in terms of ability and willingness to pay for the energy consumed, reduction in 
poverty,  improvement  in  health  and  education  services,  improvement  in  the 
status of women, and environmental benefits; 
(vii)  identify  (a)  the  least-cost  option  for  meeting  the  projected  demand  and  (b) 
opportunities for improving supply-side efficiencies and energy conservation that 
form part of the least-cost plan; 
(viii)  estimate the public and private sector investments likely to occur, explore ways 
to increase private sector participation, and determine the financing gap to meet 
the increasing electricity demand in rural areas in the next 10 years;

10  Appendix 3 
(ix)  draw up an economically feasible power supply expansion program (generation, 
transmission, and distribution) to be implemented over a 10 year period; and 
(x)  in accordance with ADB’s Poverty Reduction Strategy, demonstrate qualitatively 
and quantitatively how the program will benefit mostly the poor and will help the 
country  achieve  socially  inclusive  development  in  terms  of  pro-poor  growth, 
social development, and good governance. 
 
4.  To formulate a medium-term investment plan for rural electrification using the following 
approach, the consultants will do the following: 
(i)  in  consultation  with  the  Government,  select  a  representative  sample  of 
villages/settlements  that  can  derive  maximum  benefit  from  electrification, 
expansion, or upgrading of power supply in the next 5 years based on the 
expansion program under para. 3(vi); 
(ii)  carry out 3-4 prefeasibility studies in strict coordination with the Fiji Electricity 
Authority and other government agencies and other stakeholders, including the 
resettlement plan, if required; 
(iii)  one  study  will  focus  on  extension  of  electricity  supply  to  the  sample  of 
villages/settlements  through  expansion  or  upgrading  of  existing  systems  and 
construction of new systems; develop outline projects for extension of supply in 
each  sample  village/settlement  to  meet  the  existing  loads  and  load  growth; 
prepare basic cost estimates and estimate the economic and financial internal 
rates of return of each individual project in accordance with ADB’s guidelines; 
and quantify, where possible, economic and social indicators described in para. 
3(iii); 
(iv)  a second study, complementing the ongoing Global Environment Facility-United 
Nations  Development  Programme  and  the  forthcoming  Economic  and  Social 
Commission for Asia and the Pacific projects, will assess the market potential for 
commercially proven renewable energy technologies such as photovoltaic, wind, 
biomass, micro- and mini-hydropower, and hybrid systems to augment power 
generation capacity in the agreed sample villages/settlements; 
(v)  ensure that in carrying out the studies, the opinions of key stakeholders are 
particularly reflected, to make certain that poor and vulnerable consumers benefit 
from the project; 
(vi)  assess  the  opportunities  for  demand-side  management  in  the  sample 
villages/settlements, describe current energy conservation measures, review the 
institutional arrangements for energy conservation, outline the scope of potential 
new demand-side management projects, and prepare cost estimates; 
(vii)  examine the impediments that poor people face in availing of power supply and 
income generation; 
(viii)  value the level of subsidies required to properly operate and maintain the rural 
electrification, the villages/settlements ability to pay, and the expected impact on 
the national budget; and 
(ix)  based  on  the  studies,  formulate  an  economically  and  financially  feasible 
investment plan for the rural electrification over a 5-year period, and recommend 
elements of this investment plan that could form a project for ADB financing. 
 
B.  Phase II (approximately 9 person-months international, 6 person-months domestic) 
 
5.   The consultants will prepare a complete feasibility study for a proposed ensuing project.

6.   For the engineering and planning aspects, the power engineer consultant(s) will 
 
(i)  confirm the least-cost generation expansion plans for each island in the project, 
including an analysis of renewable energy alternatives; 
(ii)  provide technical justifications for the project and technical specifications for each 
component,  taking  into  account  existing  safety  and  quality  standards  and 
selection criteria for proposed villages/settlements; 
(iii)  prepare detailed cost estimates for the project and present the cost estimates in 
ADB format; 
(iv)  outline  the  project  implementation  and  procurement  arrangements  including 
contract packaging and the project implementation schedule; 
(v)  outline the financing requirements of the project and identify possible sources of 
financing,  including  opportunities  for  commercial,  export  credit,  and  official 
cofinancing, as well as the possibility of future private sector participation; and 
(vi)  assess the likely technical risks facing various aspects of the project and carry 
out a sensitivity analysis to check the viability of the project under these risks. 
 
7.  For  the  economic  and  financial  analysis,  the  energy  economist/financial  analyst 
consultant(s) will 
 
(i)  carry  out  an  economic  analysis  based  on  ADB’s  Guidelines  for  Economic 
Analysis of Projects, specifically including power demand analysis, least-cost and 
equalizing  discount  rate  analysis,  poverty  impact  analysis,  economic  viability 
analysis, and risk analysis; 
(ii)  incorporate  into  the  economic  analysis  an  economic  quantification  of 
environmental impacts and other externalities due to the Project following ADB’s 
guidelines; and discuss clearly and present the assumptions and methodology. 
(iii)  incorporate into the economic analysis an assessment of pro-poor impact of the 
project in terms of ADB’s poverty reduction strategy, taking into account rural 
electrification and other linkage effects; 
(iv)  perform a comprehensive and detailed financial analysis of the project based on 
ADB’s Guidelines for Preparation and Presentation of Financial Analysis; include 
an analysis of cost recovery, willingness to pay, affordability, and subsidy; 
(v)  prepare a financing plan for the project, with consideration of possible private 
sector involvement; and identify the sources and options for mobilizing financial 
resources  for  implementing  rural  electrification’s  short-term  investment  plan 
developed in Phase I and, specifically, the project; 
(vi)  estimate  future  tariff  increases  needed  for  rural  electrification  to  generate 
satisfactory financial performance indicators and ensure financial viability of the 
project;  
(vii)  value the level of subsidies required, if any (as well as the best way to ensure 
that subsidies are controlled); and  
(viii)  assess the likely financial uncertainties and risks facing the project, carry out 
sensitivity analysis, and develop measures to mitigate the risks identified and 
propose a suitable risk management program. 
 
8.   For the tariff analysis, the institutional/financial analyst consultant will 
 
(i)  review and describe the current tariff structure and end-consumer tariff levels in 
the  project  area,  and  review  information  available  on  consumption  and 
expenditure of fuels in rural communities concerned;

12  Appendix 3 
(ii)  based on the long-run marginal cost and the existing end-consumer tariff levels, 
estimate the economic subsidies in tariff for different consumer categories under 
consideration,  present  aggregate  amounts  of  subsidies,  and  establish  the 
rationale for subsidies and impacts on the power supply; 
(iii)  discuss the impact of existing tariff structure/levels on efficient use of existing 
power system facilities and private sector participation; evaluate the impact of the 
possible  tariff  increase  required  to  meet  financial  targets  of  the  project  and 
affordability of that increase to different user classes; and 
(iv)  recommend an appropriate tariff strategy and subsidy mechanism for rural areas 
consistent with the ADB policy on subsidies that would make a basic supply of 
electricity affordable to the poor users. 
 
9.  For the environmental, social, and poverty reduction aspects, the environmental/social 
consultant(s) will 
 
(i)  prepare  an  initial  environmental  examination  or  environmental  impact 
assessment for the Project, following ADB’s guidelines; 
(ii)  prepare a summary environmental report following ADB’s format, submit the draft 
summary for review, and incorporate any subsequent comments in completing 
the summary; 
(iii)  assess the role of women as contributors to and beneficiaries of the project, and 
the benefits for or adverse impacts on minority nationalities, if any, in accordance 
with  ADB’s  Policy  on  Indigenous  Peoples;  prepare  a  social  analysis  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Incorporation of Social Dimensions in ADB 
Operations; 
(iv)  if significant numbers of project-affected people are identified, develop a land

10.  Regarding institutional issues, the institutional consultant will 
 
(i)  present  the  organizational  aspects  of  implementation  arrangements  for  the 
project; identify areas that require assistance from international consultants for 
institutional strengthening; and prepare terms of reference for the consultants, to 
complete a full institutional assessment of both institutions and the project; and 
(ii)  in anticipation of the modifications that will be spun off to be responsible for 
development and management of the power sector outside rural electrification,

C.  Reporting Requirements 
11.  The following reports will be prepared by the consultants and submitted simultaneously 
to the Government and ADB: 
 
(i)  an inception report 4 weeks from the commencement of services detailing initial 
findings and recommendations for the future direction of the TA; 
(ii)  brief monthly reports summarising the progress of work, major findings, and 
notation of problem areas such as lack of data and other impediments that could 
hamper the TA; 
(iii)  an interim report on the completion of phase I setting forth the findings of this 
phase and making recommendations for the direction of work for phase II; the 
report will be reviewed by the concerned parties during the review period and 
discussed at a tripartite meeting, following which ADB, with the agreement of the 
Government, will approve the activities covered in phase II; 
(iv)  a  draft  final  report  incorporating  the  findings  of  phases  I  and  II  containing 
especially a comprehensive proposal and institutional formation plan based on 
the recommendations of the consultants consistent with the ADB country strategy 
and  program  for  the  Fiji  Islands  and  following  the  format  of  a  report  and 
recommendation  to  the  president  (RRP)  with  appendixes;  a  further  tripartite 
meeting  may  be  convened,  if  deemed  necessary  to  facilitate  a  participatory 
workshop, to discuss the draft report; and 
(v)  a final report, based on the draft final report, incorporating the comments and 
view received on the draft.
